Award.AwardTitle: Single Particle Investigation of Environmental Chemical Processes using Nano-Impact Collision Techniques
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program, Professor E. Silvana Andreescu of Clarkson University is studying the chemical processes that occur at the surface of individual nanoparticles upon exposure to environmental contaminants. To meet this challenge, a new method based on measurements of the collision events of nanoparticles with a microelectrode is developed. The integrated characterizational approach can be used to assess nanoparticle stability and predict their change as a result of exposure to the environment. These studies provide new data for understanding the relationship between nanoparticle properties and their behavior under environmental conditions. Since nanoparticles are used in many consumer products (such as soaps and make-up), increasing our knowledge of their changes in the environmental has significant economic and societal implications. This research provides training for graduate and undergraduate students, especially women and minorities, who have demonstrated significant promise for career development and leadership. The project also provides undergraduate research experience to underrepresented minority students from three 4-year public colleges that usually do not have access to research to broaden their education.

The project focuses on the development of a new electrochemical collision method for the investigation of the surface properties, size-dependent effects and redox reactivity of model metal and metal oxide nanoparticles. Changes in oxidation state, surface adsorption / desorption and reaction kinetics are evaluated using collision electrochemistry and the results are correlated with a suite of spectroscopic and surface characterization methods. These experiments determines how environmental constituents and solution chemistry affect the surface properties and reactivity of individual nanoparticles, and establish the mechanism of these interactions. The development of a new methodology for studying nanoparticles by collision electrochemistry has potential for broad application as a complementary and inexpensive tool for particle characterization and environmental screening purposes. These studies provide new data for understanding the relationship between nanoparticle characteristics and their behavior under environmental conditions.

A large diversity of engineered nanoparticles (NPs) has been implemented in commercial applications, which has resulted in the release of NPs in the environment. Understanding the physical properties of these nanoscale entities and their associated reaction kinetics, surface and interfacial chemical reactions is crucial for monitoring their effect on the environment and human health. The goal of this research was to further our understanding of the environmental chemical processes that occur at the surface of NPs so that we can predict their reactivity, explore it for useful purposes, or prevent damaging effects. To achieve our goal we used a newly developed nanoimpact electrochemical method that allows investigation of the redox processes, surface chemisorption and complexation, with unprecedented sensitivity levels, at the level of individual NPs. The project also included activities to develop educational materials for graduate and upper level undergraduate students to train them in sustainable nanotechnology, understanding materials properties and applications of electrochemistry to study nanointerfaces.

Work in this project enabled the fundamental understanding of the mechanism of NP reactivity, their changes in the environment and their interaction with environmental contaminants.  This knowledge is critical to the fundamental understanding of the risks associated with the release of NPs into the environment, for their safe implementation and practical use. Fast analysis of the adsorption capacity of these NPs, and potentially of other NP systems can help in the identification and screening of sorbents considered as materials for membranes and filtration systems to remove heavy metals from contaminated waters, among other applications. The outcome of this work includes: 1) the development of novel methods for studying and characterizing NPs, 2) mechanistic information on the interaction and reactivity of NPs with heavy metal contaminants and 3) exploration of novel concepts to detect and categorize NPs. The project demonstrated the capabilities of nanoimpact electrochemistry as a novel tool for NP characterization and for studying their interactions in environmental systems. The method can be used as a general platform for the characterization and screening of nanoscale materials and their interactions, being particularly useful in studies of surface properties including surface reactivity, metal ion adsorption and speciation. This approach could complement or bypass costly characterization methods and allow screening of sorbents for environmental remediation applications.

The project provided ample opportunities for graduate and undergraduate student training in environmental chemistry, material science and electrochemistry. Experiments to demonstrate the use of electrochemistry to characterize surfaces and interfaces and to illustrate the use of NPs for environmental sensing and remediation have been introduced in the Spectroscopy and Sustainable Nanotechnology lectures at Clarkson. Educational experiments to illustrate concepts of sustainable nanotechnology as well as applications, fate, transport and transformation of nanoparticles in the environment are appealing to students, as demonstrated by the interest expressed by students in undergraduate and graduate classes, and participation in research. Three graduate students successfully defended their thesis and have secured industry or postdoctoral positions. A total of 8 undergraduate students have participated in this project. Research findings have been disseminated broadly nationally and internationally, through publications in materials, environmental chemistry and electrochemistry journals, lectures and conference presentations at national and international meetings. Results have been disseminated in 11 peer-reviewed publications in mainstream journals, 2 book chapters, and presented in over 30 presentations at local, national and international meetings with undergraduate and graduate students co-authors.
